Class ArrayOp

  • java.lang.Object
    • ArrayOp

  • public class ArrayOp
extends java.lang.Object
    The ArrayOp class provides operations on arrays of bytes.

    The input and returned values for each methods are integers or byte[] of fixed length. Error message will be thrown if the length of input is incorrect.

    All components of the input are assumed to be nonnegative integers. All components of the output will be nonnegative integers too. For substract and binom, we check first that the first input is greater or equal to the second input so the operation works in the naive way.

    Since:
    August 25, 2019.
    Version:
    1.1.2
    Author:
    Yu-jong Tzeng

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ArrayOp(int n)
      Before doing any operations, the class builds a table of all binomial coefficients with m (<= n) choose k elements for any k.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArrayOp

        public ArrayOp(int n)
        Before doing any operations, the class builds a table of all binomial coefficients with m (<= n) choose k elements for any k. n is the required length for inputs.
        Parameters:
        n - The max parameter can be taken for binomial coefficients. It is also the required length for inputs and outputs.

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public byte[] add(byte[] c,
                  byte[] d)
        Add two arrays componentwisely.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        The componentwise sum of the inputs.

      • binom

        public long binom(byte[] c,
                  byte[] d)
        Product of componentwise binomial coefficients. Every component of the first input must be greater or equal to the second input.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        The product of all C[ci][di] (C[n][k] is the binomial coeffient).

      • greater

        public boolean greater(byte[] c,
                       byte[] d)
        Return true if c >= d.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        True if c.length == d.length and c[i] >= d[i] for all i.

      • I

        public int I(byte[] c)
        Compute Ic.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1* c1 + 2* c2 + 3 * c3 + ....

      • I

        public int I(byte[] c,
             int index)
        Compute Ic only to the given index.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        index - int
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1* c1 + 2* c2 + 3 * c3 + .... + index * cindex.

      • J

        public long J(byte[] c)
        Compute I^c.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1^(c1) + 2^(c2) + 3^(c3) + ....

      • substract

        public byte[] substract(byte[] c,
                        byte[] d)
        Substract the second input from the first input. Every component of the first input must be great or equal to the second input.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        The componentwise difference of the inputs. Send error message if the length of c and d are not equal to n.

      • sum

        public int sum(byte[] c)
        Compute |c|.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return the sum of all ci.
